findings.interpretation: Intratumoral mRNA-vaccinated or combination-treated tumors showed a notably larger fraction of proteins represented in the immunopeptidome, indicating broader antigen display.

findings.comparator_or_baseline: combination or vaccine arm versus comparator
findings.interpretation: MHC-I-presented proteins roughly doubled, supporting expansion of the antigenic peptide repertoire potentially more visible to CD8+ responses.
Vaccinated patients in the metastatic cohort had improved survival compared with unvaccinated patients under ICI treatment, reaching the reported significance threshold.
The reported normalized interferon response increased after intratumoral mRNA vaccination, consistent with innate activation in tumors.
PD-L1 levels increased in tumor tissue, supporting the biologic rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.
CD8+ T-cell density increased approximately 1.8-fold, consistent with improved immune infiltration after sensitization strategies.

findings.comparator_or_baseline: pooled across repeat experiments and matched controls
findings.interpretation: The preclinical evidence combines substantial mouse observations from both efficacy and control arms to contrast treatment combinations and controls.

controls_or_null_results.statement: Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.
ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline settings.
Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce sensitization benefits.
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the sensitization benefit.
